awd_titl_txt: GEM:  The Generation of Falling-Tone Chorus and Scattering of Particles by Chirped Waves
awd_abstract_narration:
Plasma waves called "chorus" are thought to be one of the most important waves for creating the high-energy electrons in the radiation belts from lower energy populations and are also believed to be involved in their loss through scattering into the atmosphere.  Chorus waves are radio waves in the acoustic frequency range.  If converted to acoustic waves they sound like whistling or chirping, hence the name.  Fine structures in the waveform called rising and falling tones are the source of these chirping sounds.  The rising tones have received a lot of attention, with several mechanisms suggested for their formation.  Not so for the falling tones. This project will investigate further a new mechanism for the generation of falling tones and examine the interaction of radiation belts electron with chorus - both rising and falling tones.  Research into these waves benefits not only the field of space physics but also plasma physics and fusion.  In addition the project will provide training for a postdoctoral student and research support for an early-career scientist (the proposer) at the New Jersey Institute of Technology. 

There are significant differences in the mechanisms that have been proposed to generate chorus (focusing mostly on rising tones) compared to the new mechanism suggested for falling tones.  Most current theories conclude that plasma density variations and/or inhomogeneity of the magnetic field are necessary to generate chorus.  In fact, for rising tone chorus, simulations show that spectral characteristics of the chorus are directly related to the geomagnetic field inhomogeneity.  However, the falling tone waves have much more oblique wave normal angles and, as a result, more resonances with plasma electrons are possible.  Competition between resonances that cause growth and damping of the waves can make them marginally stable, resulting in nonlinear effects that produce chirping.  This new picture of falling tone chorus generation along with scattering of electrons by chorus will be investigated through the combined use of analytic model developments and computational particle in cell (PIC) and Tristan-mp code runs. The roles of various plasma parameters will be determined from runs of a 1D Vlasov code, which solves for the time evolution of the electron distribution.

por.por_cntn:
1)     Whistler waves play important role in space plasmas. They can resonantly interact with electrons, scattering and accelerating them. In particular, in the Earth's inner magnetosphere whistler-mode chorus waves are one of the main factors controlling the outer radiation belt dynamics. Despite being studied strenuously for the last 30 years, the generation mechanisms of rising and falling tone chorus waves, and whistler wave in general, remain an active area of research. We performed a comprehensive investigation of chorus wave generation via whistler anisotropy instability using the TRISTAN-MP PIC code. We obtained rising and falling-tone chorus waves in our simulations and studied how the wave properties depend on plasma and magnetic field parameters. In particular, we demonstrated that for rising-tone chorus waves there is a correlation between the background magnetic field inhomogeneity and the wave frequency chirping rate. We also confirmed the theoretical description of the rising-tone chorus wave generation, which associates these waves with a phase space hole formation.

2)     Using the TRISTAN-MP PIC code, we studied whistler wave generation via the so-called whistler heat flux instability, which operates when there are several counter-streaming electron populations (as often happens in the solar wind, for example). We investigated the non-linear evolution of this instability and demonstrated that there is a correlation between linear growth rates and the saturated field amplitudes. This result can be used in satellite data analysis to predict the amplitudes of the whistler waves when an unstable electron distribution function is observed. Another interesting result provided by these simulations is that the heat flux, while being the source of free energy for the wave generation, does not change significantly as the instability develops and saturates. The saturation happens due to a local deformation of the electron distribution function that does not affect the heat flux substantially.

3)     We investigated electron energization via resonant wave-particle interaction with magnetospheric chorus waves with varying frequency. From the theoretical perspective, the energy variation of the electrons trapped into a resonance with a wave depends on the sign of effective inhomogeneity. The effective inhomogeneity is a combination of two terms, one is associated with the spatial inhomogeneity, and another one is related to wave chirping. Close to the equator, the second term is the dominant one, and, for the falling-tone chorus waves, it results in the decrease of the energy for the trapped particles, when they propagate to the equator. To study how the frequency variation of the chorus waves affects particles statistically, we performed simulations for a large ensemble of particles. Our results indicate that the negative frequency variation of the falling-tone chorus waves might substantially reduce the efficiency of the electron energization, as compared to rising-tone waves or constant frequency waves. For a certain population of the trapped particles that get trapped close to the equator, the net energy change might even become negative, so they get de-energized.

4)     An important part of global radiation belt models is the boundary condition on the ionosphere-magnetosphere boundary. At this boundary, one needs to set the appropriate reflection coefficients for the waves. Electromagnetic whistler waves propagate to the lower ionosphere, where the reflection and collisional damping occur. To account for this one needs the full-wave description for the wave propagation in the ionosphere. In order to calculate wave properties in the ionosphere, full-wave approach is required. The project allowed addressing this problem and to completing a study on wave propagation in the ionosphere. We developed a numerical code, using the Abramov's method to stabilize full-wave equations, and model the whistler wave propagation in the ionosphere. The most interesting results that we obtained are the quasi-periodic behavior of the transmission and reflection coefficients and the correlation between them and the resonant structure of the wave-field at the ground. The latter can be described by two parameters: length of the Earth-ionosphere wave guide and the number of resonance.

5)     The project allowed introducing important modifications to the TRISTAN-MP code. We added the possibility to initialize multiple electron populations, which is important for the Earth's magnetosphere where electron distribution function is often quite complex, consisting of several distinct populations. We also added a quite start procedure which is important for performing simulations with low-amplitude waves, because it reduces the statistical noise typical of PIC codes.

6)     The project funded a post-doctoral researcher who then has been promoted to an Assistant Research Professor. In the course of the project, an undergraduate student joined the project team. He successfully graduated and got accepted for a PhD program at a different university. The project allowed him learning many theoretical aspects and modeling techniques in space plasma physics, he participated at scientific conferences presenting his results.
